question: is standing at the end of a long conference table as the NETWORK BRASS glares at him. Gentlemen, let me be the first to say, in all sobriety, that I'm as shocked and outraged as all of --
answer: Save it for the papers, Stokes. We've got nervous sponsors and an angry public -- a combination uglier than two monkeys fucking. What are you doing about it?

question: Well, sir, I'm currently in the process of compiling a list of viable replacements and it's my hope...
answer: Clean replacements? With background checks? I assure you, Mr. Stokes, this network cannot survive another Rainbow Randolph. The goddamn P.R. department looks like the Jim Jones camp. Whoever takes that slot has to be a straight arrow. Clean as a whistle. Squeaky fucking clean.

question: Bumble Bee Billy?
answer: Wife beater.

question: Square Dance Danny?
answer: Still appealing the mail fraud thing.

question: Skippy Black and the Tippy Trolls?
answer: Black was deported, and the trolls... well, who gives a shit. This is impossible. If I ever see that Rainbow Randolph again I'll strangle him. Choke the life out of him. Squeeze his scrawny neck until his eyes pop out of his skull and bounce off the walls...

question: Before indulging such cheery fantasies, let's just concentrate on saving my job. Shall we?
answer: Sorry, Frank.

question: What's going on with Sheldon Mopes these days.
answer: Oh my God. Have we sunk to that level already? Smoochy the Rhino? What a sap.

question: Sap's just the pill we need right now. Mopes is a straight arrow. Always has been.
answer: The guy can't get arrested, Frank. He can't even break into the birthday party circuit. Last I heard he was working hospitals and nursing homes. He's a joke.

question: The truth of the matter is, a successful children's show has always depended on two simple elements
answer: I probably have ten acts in my development file -- acts I've been cultivating -- that are more deserving than Sheldon Mopes.

question: And each one a moral question mark. Something I can't risk at the moment.
answer: We can do better than this guy, Frank. He brings nothing to the table.

question: Except ethics. With Mopes, there's never been a whiff of controversy. The man's an ethical, harmless, cornball. In short, a glass of milk on two legs.
answer: Don't ask me to do it. You know I'll do anything for you, but please... not this...

question: Mr. Mopes?
answer: Yeah?

question: I, uh, saw your performance tonight. Very... ... spirited.
answer: Really? Thanks. I would've done a longer set if that guy hadn't pulled a knife on the security guard. Once the pepper spray starts flyin', that's it for the encores.

question: Yes, that did put a damper on the evening, didn't it?
answer: Are you a new patient? On the juice, as we say?

question: Ah, no. But it's sweet of you to assume so.
answer: 'Nora Bishop. V.P. of Development. Kidnet.' Good gravy. You work for Kidnet?

question: As stated.
answer: Well, it's a pleasure to meet you, Nora. A real honor. Hey, you hungry? Soy dogs... never thought I'd live to see the day. Organic, rich in natural protein, and nobody gets killed. Although I do feel bad for the beans. Just kidding. Sure you don't want one?

question: Believe it or not, no.
answer: So anyway, like I was saying, people always tell me, 'You gotta network, Sheldon... you gotta sell yourself... or you'll be playing the drug clinics and shopping centers the rest of your life.' And you know what I tell 'em?

question: I haven't the foggiest.
answer: I tell 'em, it's not about the old handshake and back slap game. It's not about adding fuel to the shlock machine. It's about doing good work. Having integrity. Making people happy and delivering a positive message. Foundations are built with concrete, not plaster of Paris! This is concrete! This is integrity!

question: I can see that.
answer: Sorry. As you can imagine, living by your convictions can be a little stressful at times.

question: We all have our cross to bear.
answer: See, I was raised by my grandfather, and Grandpop paved driveways for a living...

question: Are we going into a story?
answer: Thing is, he didn't really pave them. Just covered them with black paint. Of course, once the first rain came along, people realized they'd been swindled. I vowed to myself back then that I'd never make a living through deception. Never. Whadda ya think of them apples?

question: The reason I'm here today, Mr. Mopes, as fate would have it, Kidnet is currently looking for a performer with... convictions. And integrity. Someone like... ... yourself.
answer: Yeah, right. Got any more jokes?

question: I don't think I could top that one.
answer: Hold the phone. You're telling me that Kidnet is finally ready to do a show of Smoochy quality? Of Smoochy caliber?

question: Yes... I believe we're ready to push ourselves to that level.
answer: I knew this day would come! After all these years I finally meet someone in the business who gets what I do. Who gets what I'm all about. You get me, don't you, Nora?

question: I'm afraid so.
answer: Well, Miss V.P. of Development... let's go make history!

question: I was starting to think that maybe you weren't coming.
answer: I agreed to meet you, didn't I? I had a dinner engagement.

question: Really? You know, I used to have dinner engagements. Sometimes four, five a night. Dinner... drinks... I was the toast of the fucking town.
answer: Don't start, Randolph. Please.

question: Cars, boats, whores and horses, I had 'em all. When I walked into a restaurant, ten guys reached for my hat. When I stood up to take a piss, they cleared the rest room. I'd walk down the street and traffic stopped, mouths gaped. You know why? You know why, Frank? I was Rainbow fucking Randolph! That's why!
answer: Are you through?

question: What? You're in a hurry? You don't have time for me? The guy who earned for you? The guy who put those fucking suits on your back and the pheasant au vin in your Brooklyn mouth?
answer: I think it's fair to say we helped each other.

question: You gotta fix it, Frank. You gotta get me my slot back. How can I sit around while that rhinoceros... that horned carpetbagger gets a free ride on my dime? You and I have history, Frank! Please!
answer: There's nothing I can do for you. Nothing. You're a pariah. I can't even be seen with you.

question: Don't do this to me, Frank. I'm in deep, deep shit. They kicked me out of the corporate penthouse... I got bookies breathing down my neck. I'm homeless! Don't you hear what I'm saying? I'm not gonna make it! The clock's ticking! Put yourself in my shoes, for Christ's sake!
answer: The ugly truth is, your shoes have become my shoes. As long as the rhino's on the air, everything's by the book. No skim, no percentage. Nothing. The network wanted squeaky clean and they got it. And believe me, Mopes is sparkling. You're totally broke? You don't have a dime left to your name?

question: Again, these are just prototypes. I've been assured by FunZone that all the bugs will be worked out before Christmas. Okay, so let's recap before we break up... Yes to the Smoochy ice pops. No to the Smoochy string cheese. And we're in a dick-measuring contest with Brown & Brown over the shampoo split.
answer: Okay, time out, people! If I may interject, I think we're putting the cart before the horse here... Smoochy's still earning the trust of the kids. We don't want to compromise that by asking them to buy shampoo and cheese. How 'bout we just concentrate on doing the best show possible. Huh? Without all the bells and whistles and rickata-rackita. What do you say, guys?

question: Oh, damn.
answer: No problem, I'll get it.

question: Shut the door please, John. Now lock it. Thank you.
answer: Hey, Nora, wait up. Good meeting today. I thought we tackled some hot issues. Although, I'll be honest, there were a few times that I felt my voice wasn't being heard.

question: I think that's a conservative estimate.
answer: I just want the show to have some weight, you know? Some substance. Silly songs, sure -- but with a message. Pop quiz

question: Do you sense my complete lack of interest?
answer: Try two thousand. Covering every topic from how yummy vegetables are to the importance of donating plasma. Don't you get it, Nora? I'm a valuable resource. Use me.

question: Can I make this real easy for you?
answer: Sure.

question: The only reason you're on TV right now is because Rainbow Randolph is a degenerate scumbag. I didn't discover you, I delivered you. Like a bag of groceries. I have a bigger emotional investment in my nail polish. So don't peddle your sap to me, rhino. Your job is just to smile and nod your head.
answer: ... No, no, you misunderstand me. It's not that I'm literally comparing Captain Kangaroo to Jesus Christ. I'm just saying that the Captain, like Christ, was someone you could believe in. Those guys didn't care about bells and whistles and rickita-rackata. It was all about the work. Especially Jesus. Forget about it. That's okay, my good man. Three's my limit. Back in my college days I could put away a carton of the stuff.

question: ... No, no, you misunderstand me. It's not that I'm literally comparing Captain Kangaroo to Jesus Christ. I'm just saying that the Captain, like Christ, was someone you could believe in. Those guys didn't care about bells and whistles and rickita-rackata. It was all about the work. Especially Jesus. Forget about it. That's okay, my good man. Three's my limit. Back in my college days I could put away a carton of the stuff.
answer: Gimme a Five Crown. Smoochy the Rhino. Wow. I'm a big fan.

question: Gee, thanks. I usually don't get recognized without my horn.
answer: Burke Bennett. I represent kid show talent. Look, Shel, Frank Strokes ain't in the business to make you rich. He's in it to make Frank Stokes rich. That's how these network goons operate.

question: That's so sad. Is it just me, or is that sad?
answer: You know, years ago, a client of mine, Dicky Gimble, was having a problem...

question: Wow, you represented Dicky Gimble?
answer: Yeah, before the asshole found religion. Anyway, Stokes was trying to screw my boy out of some merchandising points. Claimed he had a warehouse full of Dicky dolls that weren't moving. Now Frank and I are old friends, so I say to him, 'Okay, cock, show me the warehouse' -- see, I know the fucking warehouse is in the Bronx, and I know it's emptier than my wife's head. To make a long story short, I walk out with a check for a hundred grand and Stokes is sitting there with his thumb up his ass.

question: That's very amusing, but I don't care about Smoochy dolls and Smoochy floor wax... I just want more creative input. This rhino came from my womb. I bore him, I nursed him, and dammit... I should be the one who raises him!
answer: Shel, it's all about the dough. After you get the money, you get the power. And after you get the power, you can have Smoochy walk on stage with a hard-on if you want.

question: It's funny, that never crossed my mind.
answer: Unfortunately, until then... you're just another puppet in the prop room. Give me a call when you're ready, kid. I'll cut the strings and open the magic door for you.

question: Unfortunately, until then... you're just another puppet in the prop room. Give me a call when you're ready, kid. I'll cut the strings and open the magic door for you.
answer: I saw you! I saw you in there... at my table... talking to him.

question: Yeah, so what do you want? A parade?
answer: You're my agent! Or did you forget that?

question: Not anymore, pal. You're a cigarette butt. Go lay in the gutter.
answer: Ah! They're beautiful! A perfect batch of cock cookies for a very special rhino. Oh yes, you're going to learn about shame, my dear Smoochy. And I'm your professor.

question: Excuse me, Nora. Why was the 'Please and Thank You Song' cut?
answer: Because it's sappy and it takes away from the 'Cookie Song.'

question: Takes away? It enhances it! The cookie song is a meaningless piece of fluff without the 'Please and Thank You' coda! That's the moral anchor! That's where the lesson is! You can't sell the sizzle without the steak!
answer: It's cut. And I want the 'Cookie Song' lyrics changed back to the way they were originally scripted.

question: I can't do that. I will not condone children consuming endless amounts of refined sugar. I have to look myself in the mirror every morning.
answer: This is network television, not a sprout farm. We're here to sell sugar and plastic. That's what keeps the lights on.

question: You're treating me like a puppet. You know that? Well, guess what? I am not your puppet.
answer: Since when? Now get your spongy orange ass out there and dance for the cameras.

question: Bon soir, la Smoochy. Welcome to fatty Arbuckle-land. Don't worry, little ones. Rainbow Randolph will return... After these messages!
answer: Boy, all that jiggyin' and ziggyin' sure makes a fella hungry! Now if only I had my super duper, super secret, super special... Right-o-riffic! Magic Cookie Bag, I command thee! Come to your lord and master! 'Lookie, lookie, lookie, here comes the cookies! Fresh and organic, no need to panic! Right from the soil, no tropical oils! Sweetened with juice, for an energy boost! Fiber galore, you'll be askin' for more...' Oooh... just the smell of unprocessed flour makes my tummy do somersaults!

question: Whatever that means, you fucking retard.
answer: His puffy orange hand reaches for the bag's clasp as the MUSIC reaches its CRESCENDO.

question: He's practically shaking as he suppresses an insane laugh. Give 'em a cookie... give 'em a cookie...
answer: He reaches into the bag, and with a grand flourish, pulls out a flaming red penis cookie. The cookie is somewhat misshapen and not perfectly formed. Smoochy gets a big grin. Wow! Look at this cookie, kids! A rocket ship!

question: Heaven, hell, and everything in between. To the star and new executive producer of the Smoochy show! May your reign be a long and healthy one!
answer: I'm still in shock. Complete creative control, part ownership of the show, discretion over merchandising and a dressing room with a toilet! Am I dreaming or what?

question: And don't forget the corporate penthouse. It took me six years to get that for Randolph.
answer: Boy, imagine... me, living in a penthouse. Who'd a thunk it.

question: It's called the high life, kid. Get used to it. Pretty soon you'll be burnin' one hundred dollar bills just to see Franklin break a sweat.
answer: Jeez, I hope not. I have a deep respect for money. Not to mention Ben Franklin who had some remarkable achievements in his lifetime. What's this?

question: That's your graduation present. Something you're gonna need now. Think of it as a tool of the trade.
answer: I've never owned a gun, I've never touched a gun, and I don't believe in guns. When I played cowboys and Indians as a kid, I was always the Chinese railroad worker.

question: Hiya, Smoochy! I'm Spinner! Spinner!
answer: Hi there.

question: I'm so excited to meet you! I'm Spinner!
answer: Oh... right. I saw you fight on TV once. I think it was your farewell bout.

question: You know what I love, Smoochy? I love when you do the Jiggy Ziggy dance! You know, the one you do during 'Silly Time?'
answer: You bet. That's a big one.

question: Wanna see me do it?
answer: Well, I don't know why if there's enough room here to...

question: Yeah, who is it?
answer: Open up, buddy! It's me, Randolph! It's been a long time!

question: Randy?
answer: You fucking traitor! My body's barely cold and already you work for the rhino?

question: I don't know what you're talking about.
answer: Don't lie to me! I heard all about it! You strapped that horn on faster than a cheerleader gets the clap!

question: I gotta eat, don't I?
answer: You're a Krinkle Kid! Not a Smooch-bag! Say it!

question: Rhinette!
answer: Say it

question: I'm a Rhinette. Got that? The Krinkle Kids are ten feet under. With you.
answer: I missed you so much. Can I stay here? I got no place to go. ... They kicked me out of the corporate penthouse. Big surprise. Sons-a-bitches. That's how I got this beauty. And of course, there's this... That happened after my little visit to the studio the other day. Network security. Fucking savages. I got liens, back taxes, lawyer's bills, threats against my life... I basically got the whole fucking world up my ass. It's okay, I got a loooong memory, son. What dey sow, dey gonna reap.

question: Stop doing this to yourself! Wise up! You hear me? Don't piss your life away like this.
answer: It's the rhino, Angie. He's been sent by the devil. Sent from hell to destroy me. Smoochy... is the face of evil.

question: Whenever you get a chance... I just need a second.
answer: Listen, can I call you back? Yeah, some asshole's screaming in my ear. Thanks.

question: I'm sorry, you didn't have to hang up.
answer: If I didn't you'd still be here.

question: But I am still here.
answer: I'm hoping to correct that.

question: Nora, I want us to start off on the right foot. I want you to know that I value your input and I don't want you to feel intimidated just because the power structure has changed a bit. I consider you a partner.
answer: Great. That'll come in handy if we're ever at a square dance.

question: Well, I was never much of the do- se-do type, but what I would love to do is take you out to lunch one day. You know, just two colleagues chewing the fat... forming a mutual respect... planting the seeds of cooperation...
answer: No.

question: Fair enough. If you change your mind --
answer: I won't.

question: Okay then, I'll be in my office if you need me. If you want to brainstorm about anything. Ideas and so forth. Ficus? Wow...
answer: My cousin Spinner's take quite a shine to you. Ever since you came in the restaurant. He can't stop yakkin'.

question: Well, he's a very nice man. Very sweet disposition for someone that size.
answer: So, I was wondering if maybe you could give him a little floor space.

question: I'm sorry?
answer: You know, a little part on the show. You're the executive producer now. You call the shots, right?

question: Uh, that's a very sweet offer, and I love Spinner, but TV is a complicated medium and... I mean, that would be like me getting into the ring with a prizefighter. Can you imagine such a thing? Boom. K.O.! What's the alphabet, Mommy?
answer: This makes me sad. Very, very, sad. Nothing. I'm just very sad right now. I don't want to mention names.

question: You know what? Maybe I can find Spinner a little something to do on the show. That's probably the best solution.
answer: You're a good boy, Mopes. Don't think we don't remember favors.

question: Burke, I never agreed to do an ice show.
answer: Shel, do you know what kind of cash we'll take in between the gate and concessions? A venture like this gets you money and muscle. Times twenty.

question: Ice shows represent everything I'm against. They're mindless spectacles whose main purpose is to sell overpriced sugar-water and cheap plastic toys that splinter in a kid's mouth on the ride home.
answer: Look, I know you got this fetish for ethics, but now's not the time to fly that kite. No one's ever refused a shot at an ice show.

question: Until now. Smoochy doesn't sell out, Burke. You should be proud of that. Proud that you represent a client who paves driveways, not paints them over.
answer: I'm thrilled, Shel. Knocked out.

question: Hi there.
answer: Hi.

question: Get in.
answer: Thanks anyway, but I'm going uptown.

question: Humor me, rhino. Merv Green, Sheldon. It's a pleasure to meet you.
answer: If you're hoping for an autograph, the gun's a bit much. The whole 'catch more flies with honey' thing -- it really holds water.

question: Sheldon, I represent the Parade of Hope Foundation. Maybe you've heard of us.
answer: You raise money to build children's hospitals, right?

question: We've been known to add a brick or two, sure. Sheldon, let me get right to the point -- there's talk on the street that you're pulling out of the ice show. Is that true?
answer: You know, I never agreed to an ice show, nor would I ever agree to do an ice show, and let me add that none of this is your concern, sir. Sheesh.

question: Listen carefully, son
answer: Well, I appreciate the offer, but for the gazillionth time, I'm not doing an ice show, so we have nothing to discuss. Now, if you'll just pull over, I'll get out and we'll say our toodley-dos. Far corner, please.

question: Allow me to be less murky. Starting tomorrow, Smoochy the Rhino raises his baton for Parade of Hope. Benefits, banquets, fund-raisers, I want it all. Pull over, Terry. And as far as the ice show goes... I recommend you start shopping for skates.
answer: This is unacceptable, Burke! I'm calling the authorities.

question: May I come in?
answer: Sure. Uh... are you okay?

question: I'm getting drunk and I'm not used to it.
answer: Oh. Well, not to make you feel worse, but with alcohol you're also consuming empty calories.

question: It's just that... I want to apologize, actually. And on those rare occasions when I feel the need to apologize for something, it helps if I'm, you know... shit- faced.
answer: Wow. I'm honored. Why don't we get some air?

question: I... I may have been a little harsh when we spoke the other day. A little out of line.
answer: Well, it wasn't as bad as the week before when you called me a pasty- faced, no-talent hack.

question: Yes, that was probably insensitive as well. I heard you're not doing the ice show. I find that... incredibly admirable. Why didn't you tell me?
answer: I guess I didn't want to spoil your fun. You look so content when you're berating me.

question: I'm afraid I have become a bit hardened over the years. Sincerity's an easy disguise in this business. It's hard to know who's on the level.
answer: Believe me, I'm learning that more and more every day. 'Sometimes light is really dark, Sometimes crows can sing like larks Sometimes Winter feels like Spring, Don't think you know everything.'

question: 'Rickets the Hippo'?
answer: You remember Rickets?

question: That was my favorite show when I was a kid. Rickets was the one face I knew I could trust.
answer: That's how I felt! Rickets had real depth. He was my inspiration for Smoochy.

question: Really? He was my inspiration to work in children's television.
answer: I can't believe it. I never met anyone who even remembers Rickets. Do you remember the Klunky-Wunky dance?

question: Remember it? I did it at my first communion.
answer: I'm sorry. That was a mistake, right? I didn't mean for that to hap--

question: You're not full of shit like all the others, are you?
answer: No, no.

question: You're for real, right?
answer: Yes, yes.

question: I mean, I couldn't tell... First I thought it was an act... and then I just thought you were a simp or something...
answer: Shhh... you don't have to explain...

question: I should go.
answer: Why? What's wrong? Is it the whiskey? If you have to throw up, be my guest. Anywhere you like.

question: It's just getting late. Better get that. Good night.
answer: Hello?

question: Hello?
answer: Hello, Mr. Mopes? My name is Benjamin Kunklepeck and I'm calling on behalf of 'Parents for Decency in Children's Television,' perhaps you've heard of us?

question: No, but I like where you're coming from. It's an issue very close to my heart. Why just yesterday I was commenting --
answer: Sir, we're having a banquet tomorrow and we'd be honored to have you perform for us. We would also like to present you with a plaque for your ongoing commitment to children's television. The presenter will be a young orphan with mild asthma. Can you attend?

question: Thanks for picking me up, Mr. Kunklepeck. It's very nice of you.
answer: Don't be silly. The chance to have Smoochy the Rhino perform at our little soiree? I'd carry you piggy-back through a bed of hot rusty glass if I had to.

question: Well, it's always a pleasure to help out a worthy cause. And believe me, I've learned lately that it's not all sunshine and daffodils in the land of non- profit.
answer: I just looove your show, by the way. It's such a refreshing change of pace from that dreadful embezzler... what's his name again? Rainbow something or other?

question: Randolph.
answer: Yes. Rainbow Randolph. What a scoundrel! He's probably gay too.

question: Oh, I don't know. I feel sorry for him, actually. He obviously has problems or issues that he needs to sort out.
answer: Yeah, yeah, yeah, but don't you take particular glee in that you basically stole his time slot? Helped shovel dirt onto his miserable corpse, as it were?

question: No, I would never take pleasure in someone's downfall. You know the old expression about walking a mile in another man's shoes? Well, that really holds water. Just try to imagine --
answer: Come on, he's a fucking asshole! You hate him! Admit it!

question: Uh... can we listen to the radio?
answer: Okay, they're ready for you!

question: I gotta say, this is a first -- I never performed in a tractor parts warehouse before.
answer: Well, we like to do these things no-frills. It's all about the kids.

question: Amen to that.
answer: Knock 'em dead, kid!

question: I have to talk to you.
answer: We have nothing to talk about.

question: Don't tell me you believe what they're saying!
answer: I don't have to believe anyone. The picture in the paper said it all. No one forced you to perform at that rally.

question: Perform? I barely sang one song.
answer: Well maybe next time you'll do a longer set.

question: Nora, I had no idea that was a Nazi function. None whatsoever!
answer: Funny, you'd think the fifty-foot swastika you were standing in front of might've given you a hint.

question: The papers are blowing that out of proportion. It was nowhere near that big.
answer: Look, the fact of the matter is, I don't know you, okay? Not really. So don't expect me to go out on an emotional limb here.

question: But what about the balcony? What about the Klunky-Wunky dance?
answer: I was drunk. Don't read too much into it.

question: 'Takashi Sings Tin Pan Alley for Youngsters' is the hottest show on Japanese television. The sweat shops are working overtime trying to keep up with the demand. Record albums, toys, cereal, tee shirts, you name it... Look, Stokes, let's cut the bullshit. We want Takashi in that Smoochy slot and we're willing to do whatever it takes to get it.
answer: Pardon me for saying this, but for a non-resident of this country, you speak impeccable English.

question: I'm originally from Teaneck.
answer: Ah.

question: We own every hair on this bastard's head and we're willing to share a few strands... if you get my drift.
answer: Well, it's not that simple. I have an executive board to answer to. I wish I could just snap my fingers and make a deal but --

question: You mean like this?
answer: Oh my. And what is this on my desk?

question: Two hundred grand in a Louis Vuitton duffle bag. Get our boy the slot and we'll round it off to a million. And you can keep the luggage. You're dealing with an honorable culture, Frank. We know how to play ball.
answer: Gentlemen, I suddenly feel invigorated and full of hope.

question: Hiya, cutie! So here's the good news Ahhh. Who do ya gotta blow to get a Scotch around here?
answer: You've got three seconds to pry your ass off my couch and get out.

question: Dammit, Nora! The rhino's gone! You need that slot filled and I'm ready to reclaim what's rightfully mine.
answer: Just in case you forgot, you're a criminal and a scumbag.

question: Okay, so maybe I commandeered a stray shekel or two. Big deal! Compared to what Smoochy did that's like jerking off in the supermarket.
answer: Where do you shop?

question: Come on. Have you lost all affection for me? After what we once had?
answer: That was a long time ago. I was young and stupid.

question: Why we broke up I'll never know.
answer: You turned into an asshole and I didn't love you.

question: We could've worked through all that. Damn it, Nora! The public is clamoring for me! I'm a fucking patriot! Mopes is a Nazi! He's evil! He's probably even gay! You should've seen the way he was checking me out in the car!
answer: What does that mean?

question: What does what mean?
answer: You said he was checking you out in the car. What car?

question: No... it's just a vibe! A Nazi homosexual vibe! It emanates from the television! The whole Smoochy costume... with the erect horn... I mean, what's that all about?
answer: You're talking awfully fast, Randolph.

question: I still love you! Let's go on a date!
answer: Were you at that rally? Tell me! Did you have something to do with this? Did you set Sheldon up?

question: Hi, Tommy. Hi, Spinner. Has Burke been in tonight?
answer: Haven't seen him.

question: Damn it.
answer: Something I can help you with?

question: I'm trying to sleep, asshole! Read the fucking meter some other time!
answer: You wanna tell me about the rhino?

question: Hey, this is private property, creep! And you're trespassing!
answer: Danny, go give Mr. Smiley a little back rub.

question: Easy, Spinner. Watch the ribs, buddy.
answer: I missed you so much!

question: I missed you too, champ.
answer: I've been practicing and practicing and I got real good, Sheldon. Real good! Wanna see me march?

question: Sure, why not.
answer: So you were saying you had some good news?

question: Yes. Some very good news. After giving it a lot of thought... I've decided to do the ice show.
answer: Finally! I got me a bar mitzvah boy. Today you are a man!

question: I realize now it's a sin to waste your power.
answer: Like they say, rock bottom's a college education.

question: But here's the really good news As far as food concessions go, I'll supply the refreshments. For free. Low sodium, whole wheat pretzels and apple slices. Healthy stuff. Now are you ready for the best part?
answer: I'm holding my breath.

question: All profits from ticket sales will be used to built a state-of-the- art methadone clinic in Coney Island. I'm not just talking a run-of-the- mill clinic... I'm going to build a methadone palace. A place where men and women can withdraw in luxury.
answer: Sheldon, you can't do an ice show and cut out the vendors. And more importantly, you can't cut out the Parade of Hope. It's suicide.

question: I don't like complications, Frank. You got one week to get Takashi that slot or you're gonna be shakin' hands with Buddha.
answer: Don't you understand? My hands are tied. The rhino's been exonerated. The show's more popular than ever.

question: Okay, boys, chop him up, bag him and dump him in the woods.
answer: All right! I'll take care of it! I just need time!

question: Your client is suffocating me. To make matters worse, he's caused me to veer into a hazardous situation. A situation that otherwise could have a very happy ending.
answer: Tell me more about the Asians.

question: They're ruthless. Unwavering. Unprincipled. And best of all, they know how the game is played. They respect our delicate ecosystem of mutual benefit. I'd bring you in on this, Burke. You'd be my partner on the Takashi deal. Split down the middle. We have an opportunity to get back on track here. Back to the way it was.
answer: The good old days.

question: Pre-rhinoceros.
answer: This is very sticky ground we're about to walk on.

question: Well, you're used to a little glue on your shoes.
answer: Let me poke around. Sift through the possibilities.

question: Let me poke around. Sift through the possibilities.
answer: This is what happens to guys who keep secrets, Johnny. It's not me you're fucking over, it's sick kids. You got something against sick kids, Johnny? And you tell that fat producer of yours, if he ever gives me a low head count again, he'll lose the other thumb.

question: Merv Green. How's tricks, kid?
answer: Well, if it ain't smilin' Burke. Whose bones are you pickin' today?

question: You got a minute, pally?
answer: No one freezes me out of an ice show. No one. I don't care how many fucking clinics he's trying to save.

question: Look, I'm chokin' on the same bone as you.
answer: If you're trying to aggravate me, you're doing a hell of a job.

question: I'm not here to aggravate, just educate. I think Mopes might be talking to people he shouldn't be talking to.
answer: That's an ugly string of words.

question: Hi.
answer: Hi.

question: I read about the ice show.
answer: Yeah, the papers seem to be really covering it.

question: I think it's great. What you're doing for that clinic.
answer: Thanks.

question: I just need some clarification...
answer: Don't worry. Spinner just needs a little more rehearsal. I'll get him there.

question: No I mean about us. Ever since you've been back I just feel like there's something that's not connecting.
answer: I guess I'm still readjusting a little. Like a guy who's come back from the war. Not that I'd equate my misfortune with the

question: I'm sorry, Spinner. I'm so sorry.
answer: He really loved you, Shel. And this I guarantee -- that fucking Randolph has seen his last rainbow. We're gonna find him, cut off his balls, and shove 'em up his ass.

question: Maybe you better leave it to the police.
answer: Don't forget -- that hit was meant for you, Shel. So from now on, everywhere you go, we go.

question: That's okay, Tommy. I'll be fine.
answer: Fine, nothin'. And as Christ is my witness, no one's touchin' a hair on your fuckin' head. Spinner would have wanted it that way. Alright, boys, let's get shit- faced. For Spin.

question: I didn't do it! I know you're still mad at me, but you gotta believe me.
answer: The papers say you were the mastermind.

question: Mastermind? I can barely figure out how to unzip my pants these days. Just taking a piss is a logistical nightmare.
answer: I believe you, Randy. But you can't come back to my place. They'll find you. You gotta go underground. It's heatin' up out there. Every cop in New York is looking for you. And Tommy Cotter's boys are combin' the streets. You're gonna have to stay put for a while.

question: I was an altar boy once. Did you know that? I wanted to be a priest. Do you believe in angels, Angie?
answer: Angels?

question: There was a little angel in pigtails. She was the only one who cared about me. She saved my life.
answer: You didn't want to kill yourself, Randy. You know that.

question: Perhaps it's time to heal. To accept the fact that Smoochy has won and gracefully march forward. True, I'm currently wanted for a murder I didn't commit. But I have faith. Faith that justice will prevail.
answer: Now you're talkin', kid. This is a big step... I'm proud of you.

question: Did you bring lunch?
answer: Yes.

question: Chicken and stars?
answer: Just like you asked for.

question: Can I have some, please?
answer: For a smile. Atta boy. Here, I got you some crossword puzzles and stuff to read. You okay? Randy?

question: It was a mistake! An honest mistake! All I'm trying to do is help children.
answer: You like kids, huh?

question: Yes! Of course!
answer: So you must know a few fairy tales. Danny, tell him the one about the worthless prick who gets his head chopped off.

question: No... no... no!
answer: Now you know why charities go under sometimes.

question: Can I help you with something?
answer: Yeah, honey, you can help us with something... You tell that boss of yours he better take care of the rhino problem. In my culture we honor deals or invite consequences.

question: I don't know what you're talking about and your cologne's making me nauseous. Other than that, you're great company.
answer: Spicy little thing, isn't she? Takashi gets that time slot. You hear me, girly? Tell that boss of yours we'll kill everyone at this fucking network if we have to. Starting with the pretty ones. Auf Wiedersehen, honey.

question: It's Stokes. He's behind the whole thing! He cut some kind of deal for the Smoochy slot!
answer: What are you talking about?

question: He wants you out so he can put Takashi in!
answer: Who's Takashi?

question: We'll go to the police, first thing tomorrow... straighten everything out.
answer: Oh! Goody-goody gumdrops! Vodka straight up is fine, sugar babe! Did you put on a little weight, honey? That's okay, you're still a hot little brood mare. I bet you miss the sweet sting of my riding crop. Giddy up, pony! 'Rainbow Randolph is the man. Yes he, yes he, is. He's the Prez of Rainbowland. Yes he, yes he, is. With some fun, fun here, and a laugh, laugh there. Here a dance, there a song, Everything is fun, fun. Rainbow Randolph is the King, the King of Rainbowland!'

question: Is this what you want? A Hansel and Gretel ending?! You want to be the big bad wolf?
answer: Stop! It's too hot! The heat! It's driving me mad! Go ahead, kill me! Finish me off. My life's over anyway. Everything I touch turns to shit. Put me out of my misery.

question: You're not nothing. You're bitter, misguided and I'm guessing a raging alcoholic, but you're still Rainbow Randolph. Despite everything that's happened, you once made children happy.
answer: Would you be my friend?

question: Sure.
answer: You too?

question: She's right, Sheldon. Don't make the same mistakes I did. Keep your dignity intact. Son-of-a-bitch!
answer: I appreciate everyone's concern, but I can take care of myself.

question: I tried.
answer: Okay, buddy, we have to get down to the Garden. You're welcome to stay here as long as you like. Just don't leave until I get things squared away.

question: Things are getting out of hand. We have to cover our tracks.
answer: Relax, everything's gonna work out.

question: Relax? They found Merv Green's head on the Grand Concourse! Excuse my concern.
answer: Look, we can cover all the tracks we want, but in the end we still got the same problem. We gotta finish what we started.

question: God help us...
answer: It'll all be over tonight. Buggy's gonna take care of everything.

question: Buggy? Buggy Ding-Dong? The guy who hosted 'Buggy's Bumpy Railroad'? Yeah, until he discovered the joys of Turkish black mule heroin. For the right price he'll do anything. It's amazing the guy's still alive. I don't know, Burke... this whole thing...
answer: Speak of the devil. Have a seat, Bug.

question: Buggy. You're looking good.
answer: It's time we put this thing to rest, Frank. And the way I see it... the rhino's up past his bedtime.

question: Hellooo!
answer: Randy, is that you?

question: Yes, Angelo, my little Twinkie, shouldn't you be getting ready for the big show?
answer: Listen, Buggy's been here.

question: Buggy Double D's? The Dong Man?
answer: Yeah, he lifted my backstage pass and he's braggin' that he's doing some kind of job for Burke Bennett.

question: Sheldon's in trouble. I gotta get down to the Garden.
answer: The place is crawling with cops. They'll jump on you like a trampoline.

question: Stay out of it, Tommy. This is my business.
answer: No more killin', Shel. Enough's enough. Don't destroy who you are for this piece of shit. You mean something to the kids. Don't take Smoochy away from the kids.

question: I don't know how I got pushed this far.
answer: You're only human, Shel. The important thing is... you never went over the cliff. You're a good boy. For some of us... it's too late. We'll take it from here, kid, you run along with your girl. Get on with your life.

question: Tommy, you're not going to --
answer: Don't worry. Sometimes even a rat deserves a little mercy.
